items.description: Wear estuary
items.message:
High tides, strong winds and large waves may lead to flooding tomorrow morning.
Tides will be at their highest from 8:00 AM to 13:00 PM tomorrow, 26/09/2024, with wave overtopping during these times.
Waves are forecast to overtop coastal defences at riverside footpaths and low lying land and roads. The area most affected will be Port of Sunderland Harbour.
After the high tide tomorrow morning‚ the weather is more settled and no flooding is expected.
We are closely monitoring the situation.
Be careful along beaches, promenades, coastal footpaths and roads as large waves and sea spray could be dangerous.
This message will be updated by 13:00 PM on 26/09/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Nene
items.message: Over the last 48 hours we have seen heavy rainfall in the Upper River Nene area. This means that the River Nene has risen, leading to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts also indicate that further flooding inside properties is not likely and therefore a flood warning has been removed for areas near the Dallington Brook and Brampton Branch in Northampton. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. items.description: River Adur East Branch
items.message: The River Adur has now fallen significantly. There is uncertainty in the weather forecast, but light rain on Wednesday (25/09/2024) followed by possible heavy showers through the early hours of Thursday could cause river levels to rise again. From 10:00 on 26/09/2024, minor flooding and small amounts of water could affect fields, gardens and possibly the A281 at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury. The river should peak lower than it was on Monday, and begin to fall by 22:00 on 26/09/2024. However, it is possible that another period of persistent rain with intense showers could occur throughout Thursday and into Friday (27/09/2024), which would cause river levels to rise higher. There is confidence in less rain occurring from Friday afternoon and through the weekend, which should allow river levels to return nearer to normal by Saturday afternoon at the latest. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may be affected. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 26/09/2024.

items.description: Lower Welland

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Welland, Old River Welland, Maxey Cut

items.message: Over the last few days we have seen heavy rainfall in the Lower Welland area. This means that the River Welland is now rising, which will lead to flooding of low-lying land and roads close to the river from the evening of Wednesday 25/09/2024 onwards. We expect the river to remain high throughout the next few days and flooding to gardens, driveways or outhouses is possible close to the river. Our forecasts indicate that flooding inside properties isn't currently likely and therefore flood warnings are not expected to be issued. We are constantly monitoring river levels and have staff in the field checking for blockages and clearing weedscreens. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated online and on FloodLine by 17:00 on 26/09/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Thames from Buscot Wick down to Shifford
items.message: Property flooding is expected. River levels are rising on the River Thames as a result of very heavy rainfall over the last few days. This is causing the Thames to rise and this could continue for some time. More rain is forecast on Thursday 26/09/2024. Therefore, flooding of property and roads is possible from about 22:00 this evening in Kelmscott and Bampton. Some rain is expected this evening but Thursday evening and night are likely to bring more rain to the area.  We expect river levels to continue to rise slowly and then hold steady overnight.  Our staff are liaising with councils and emergency services.  Our staff are managing weirs on the River Thames to reduce flood risk.  Move possessions and valuables off the ground or to safety.  Move family, pets and cars to safety. Don't drive through flood water. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 26/09/24, or as the situation changes.
